text: What is it with people thinking that the ground in their plug is grounding this machine!!! You're not the only one I've seen. You said, "I haven't grounded this machine but we'll see"!!! text: This is for Intermediates; not for Absolute Beginners. Saying "you could create it this way (and then draw it), but I'm going to show you another way", tells us that Fusion is very flexible. But it confuses many people. Just show one way and stay committed to that way; don't change in the middle and say "or we can do it this way". text: I'm typically not one to comment on Youtube, but thought I might add here - I watched this because I like your videos and you tend to recommend Fusion 360 (and I've seen others do it too!) but I wanted to add - I'm pretty sharp and used to CAD programs, but I feel like you zipped through some things so fast I had to go look them up outside of your video to figure out how you did what you showed. For example, your bit on mirroring the table legs, I was following along and found mine wouldn't work - I got "Compute failed" and "One or more patterns could not be intersected..." etc. I googled it and found it's because you've got to change Pattern Type from "Faces" to "Components" in the mirror window. You have it selected (likely by default) but didn't mention it to us absolute beginners :P.
video: Designing Furniture with Fusion 360 for Absolute Beginners!

text: Hello , may I suggest a solution for perfectly lined up drainage holes that you could add as an update to your video.                                      Take a drill and from underneath your window box drill up trough the drain hole into your planter for easy perfectly lined up drain holes. When building new planter boxes place the empty planters in the box and drill through the pre drilled holes in the planter into the wooden planter boxes for perfectly lined up drain holes. Happy planting, Bob Mahaney

text: I started with Sketchup many years ago, then I transitioned to Blender, but I never REALLY got the hang of it for the types of things I do. Then I got a 3D printer and discovered Fusion, and it very quickly became my go-to 3D software, for everything. Learning curve is steeper than SketchUp, for sure, but it's still way easier than more "professional" software like Blender or 3ds Max.

text: Yeaaa… I wouldn't trust those even being in the 2W range... The X-Carve CNC Milling Machine in my basement ( https://imgur.com/a/04LhFJN ) has had an *Opt Lasers PLH3D-6W-XF* Laser Head attached to it which trust a LOT more being what it is marketed as than anything else coming from the Asian regions of the world ( Unless it had _Made in Japan_ stamped on it ). I also think what most people miss out on is that those Lasers don't just pose a threat to your sight when looking into the Laser with line of sight but they also pose an issue with reflections ( light bouncing off a mirror ) and refractions ( shining a strong flashlight _through_ your hand ). Besides THAT there's also the issue with cutting certain materials - Laser cutting ABS, as an example, will emit Cyanide!
video: Is this the BEST budget Laser Engraver? Ortur Laser Master Engrave 2 Review

text:
Yeah,  well I ordered one of these and it stopped working after the first use - the laser would only run at very low levels, engraving nothing. Tried everything and apparently the laser itself has failed so I attempted to contact support at GearBest. This is where it has gone terribly wrong - they simply do not respond to requests of any kind. Is that because of Covid19? Don't think so as I could live chat with them, they are sending out advertising emails, and there is nothing on their site about the Coronavirus. So, the live chats end with "you will be contacted in this regard in 24 hours or less" which I have been told on three separate occasions and received nothing. Opened tickets on their support site are closed without any followup within a day or two and sent emails that go unanswered. 


Nice.


So I would stay away from this product and GearBest.com at all costs and just spend the extra money on a real laser engraver rather than this junk from China. You get what you pay for.


BTY, I submitted a dispute to my credit card company and they have refunded my money - even they couldn't make contact with this outfit.

text: These pre-made butcher blocks are already pretty smooth. Hand sand with the grain and only use a fine or ultra fine sand paper or sanding block. Treat it with pre-stain and then stain. Make sure the prestain and the stain are either both water-based or both oil-based. If you decide to sand in between finishes, make sure to also use something that's ultra fine like 400 grit. Also do it within 24 hours of taking the wrapping off.
video: Can I Stain a Maple Butcher Block Countertop?

text:
I'm pretty deep into Sketchup and just a baby at Fusion 360.

Sketchup crashes a lot (for me). And it can't import-export unless you want to cough up a good chunk of changed.  I can get quite a bit done. Sketch-u-cam helps a lot. It's a bit limited and buggy too.

It's a bit early in the game but F360 looks quite promising. I'm already doing things in it that would be completely hairy in sketchup.

I'm going to argue that Sketchup is great at the beginning since you can get going pretty fast with it and there's a reasonable gamut of stuff you can do with it using a 2.5D methodology. Great for the dating stage with your cnc machine. 


But if you are going to marry your cnc machine a person should add F360 to the mix. You'll be able to delve deeper.
video: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?

text:
Some nice information! However, I'm still not convinced... Lots of the stuff you showed like resizing the countertop and drawer can be done very quickly in Sketchup as well. I see all these tables and screens full of dimensions and numbers, but I think with some experience you will be faster in Sketchup in the end, since it's so easy to use.


For the organic sculpting there are very good and simple to use plugins for Sketchup. And as for printing, Sketchup can export directly to STL as well, I use it for 80% of my printer modeling (and some blender sometimes). The built-in slicer in Fusion is cool, but if you're used to a normal slicer like Cura or Slic3r already, this doesn't have much more value over using Sketchup.


About rendering...  I actually use Sketchup for this professionally,  with a plugin called Twilight Render. It may not be as powerful as for example Vray ( which also costs an insane amount of money), but it can make REALLY realistic renders, better than anything i've seen coming out of Fusion.


Now... I'm not saying that Fusion is bad; If you want to do some complex and organic modeling and product design, though it can be done, it's not very easy in Sketchup. For extremely parametric stuff, like the lego bricks you showed us, this will be better as well. But I still think people really write off Sketchup too quickly, and often overlook what that piece of software can do with some additional plugins, ESPECIALLY for interior design and non-organic stuff like that. The workflow and interface sure are infinitely more intuitive and simple than any other modeling software out there...


You're free to use what you want of course, both are valid options, but don't underestimate Sketchup if you like a really hands-on and intuitive workflow.
video: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?
